name: The Jackbox Party Pack 2
description: The sequel to the party game phenomenon The Jackbox Party Pack, featuring FIVE fresh, rib-tickling party games! Your phones or tablets are your controllers – no big mess of controllers needed. For up to 8 players plus an Audience of up to 10,000! It’s a game-night riot in a box… without the box!
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP / Vista / 7 / 8 / 10 Processor: 2 Ghz Dual Core or higher Memory: 512 MB RAM Network: Broadband Internet connection Storage: 600 MB available space Sound Card: Integrated

reviews.review_text: Do you have a lot of friends that come over to your house? This is a perfect party game. Instead of an emphasis on gameplay skill or quick reflexes, these games are much more focused on wits, intelligence, and humor. It's perfect even for people who don't usually play video games. We all know that one time when we went over to a friend's house to play Mario Kart/ Super Smash Bros or something and he crushed all of us without even trying because he's the only one who owns the godamn game damnit. There's no such advantages available here, since the game is mainly trivia/ humor based.  Another great thing is you don't have to go fiddling around with any Xbox game controllers or anything like that. There is a cool browser based system where you just have to enter a code at jackbox.tv, using any browser. This means anyone with a smartphone can easily connect to the game they want to play as long as they have an internet connection. This is genius stuff, some of the games can have up to 8 players so instead of having to fiddle with a bunch of tangled wires/ teach everyone the controls, it is simple enough to set up and play. I've had good success using Valve's Steam Link paired with this game on a large TV with a group of people, it's always a good time!  The party pack comes with these 5 games below, although you'll probably only regularly play 2 or 3 of them.  Fibbage: This game is played a lot I think, essentially some trivial question is given that nobody will likely know, it's pretty obscure stuff like 'What did Abraham Lincoln get as a present from this random governor on Independence Day?' or something similar, players have to input a good lie they think may fool everyone else, and then everyone chooses from a compiled list of lies from players and one truth embedded within. You get points for both fooling others and picking out the truth. Always a goofy fun time!  Earwax: Essentially Apples to Apples or Cards Against Humanity in audio form, everyone gets a prompt, and is given a list of random sounds to choose from. This can be pretty fun, like a prompt would say 'Superman, while drunk.' and you can respond with the sounds *Loud, Long Fart* followed with *Man Screaming*. However, the issue with this game is you don't get to hear the sound before you play it so sometimes the results are not what you expect.  Bidiots: This one is complicated. Everyone is given a different subject to try and draw on their ♥♥♥♥♥♥ little smartphones, and there's a set price to each art piece, which is kept hidden from players. Everyone gets only a few hints as to how much each piece is worth, and they take turns bidding on each art piece at an auction. Whoever makes the most profit wins. This can be pretty fun but there's quite a bit of strategy involved. It'll probably take a couple of times before people understand completely how this game works, but it's one of the deeper experiences in here, there's a lot of strategies like 'fake bidding' to raise the price of a piece you know isn't worth anything. Pretty fun but you need a group that's willing to learn a bit about the mechanics to get the most out of it.  Quiplash: Pretty popular game, a prompt is given and people write what they think would be the funniest response to it. After this, people vote on what they think is the funniest/ most apt response. It's mostly humor based, from what I can tell. I actually found this game kinda boring, there wasn't enough structure to keep my interest for too long, but you might like it.  BombCorp: Kind of a simpler Keep Talking and Nobody Explodes, this game has you defusing bombs with a group of friends. You essentially shout out instructions on how to defuse a bomb and somebody tries to defuse it without it going off. This game only has 4 players maximum and is probably better suited for a smaller group of dedicated people. There is a psuedo-story mode and looks pretty fun, but I haven't played it much.  Jackbox Party Pack 2 is a fun selections of party games that will always be a hit with friends, unless your friends are big lame-os who hate fun.

I've already had an absolute blast with this game. Spent about 4 hours trying various different modes. I think Earwax may be our new favourite! A great assortment of games for a okay price. Each game brings fun to the table. From picking surprisingly fitting sounds to match a given prompt to defusing bombs, this pack provides fun for any party night.  Small word of warning though. If you plan to play this with only a certain group of friends or two, I would not recommend playing Quiplash for a majority of the time. I know people say it's the funnest in the pack, but there is one key flaw, not with the game though. Friends may tend to repeat jokes. At first it may seem a bit funny but after spending a lot of time in it you may start to grow tired of what is a fantastic game in the pack. I would recommend not having this (or possibly Fibbage 2, it can apply there as well) to be your most played games in the pack.  To me the games that let this pack shine the most are Bomb Corp and Biddiots. Bomb Corp is a co-op game where each player gets a set of instructions (or some other form of handicap that requires the group to work together) that must be followed to diffuse bombs. If one person messes up ... BOOOOM! Back to the start of that day. It can be frustrating but fun at the same time, plus beating that one day you were stuck on is very rewarding.  Biddiots is a game where each player must draw 2 pieces of art and then bid on everyone else's art. The goal is to make the most money by buying expensive pieces for cheap. The screw mechanic from You Don't Know Jack is present in this game where you can FORCE another player into buying an art piece. It helps if you're about to win a piece you don't want or if you want to spike up the price of your piece, but be careful. If you use a screw on a player who can't bid that high, then the screw is wasted.  Overall this and the first game pack is fun. It has a lot of possibilities when playing with a pretty large crowd, plus with the new Audience function in some games it provides humongous meetups / events to have a fun game going. I could not recommend this more

The reviews are (perhaps unusually) very accurate about this game. It's not worth full price, although I did pay that much for it. Fibbage is the best game out of the bunch with the slickest, smoothest presentation. You definitely need more than 2 or 3 people to get the most out of it. As others have said, Quiplash is basically Apples to Apples/Cards Against Humanity, but the automation via the browser makes things run smoothly. Bidiots is sometimes interesting with the right group of people. Overall an entertaining and useful party option that is a no-brainer whenever it's on sale.

Jackbox is a lot of fun for having friends over—like four board games, but all you have to do is turn on the game. No pieces to lose or complicated set-up. Quiplash and Fibbage are especially fun with groups, though all the games are enjoyable. Make sure you have some way to stream the game to a TV or put it on a laptop everyone can see, though. Apple TV, chromecast, etc. will all work.
